Triggering Event: He walked into their old studio, the scent of her perfume still faintly lingering in the dust. The canvas she'd left unfinished, half-hidden under a cloth, mocked him with its incompleteness. He picked it up, fingers tracing the paint's dried edges, before setting it back down untouched. In the corner, her favorite brush lay forgotten, alone and neglected.

Its familiar scent still lingered, and he couldn't help but feel a pang of sadness as he remembered how they used to joke about him losing it during their hikes together. Now, it was just another reminder of what they'd lost.

Triggering Event: In the quiet of his study, he opened an old drawer, revealing a faded photograph of him and his ex-wife, laughing together at some long-forgotten moment. A wave of remorse washed over him as he remembered how their shared laughter had slowly eroded into bitter silence. He picked up the photo, tracing her smile with a trembling finger. The clock on the wall ticked on, each second echoing like an accusation in his quiet, empty house.

Triggering Event: A former student, now in their twenties, approaches her after class to complain about her teaching style, saying they had it easier with the previous teacher. She feels a pang of resentment, remembering that she was widowed young, while the other teacher had retired happily with their spouse still by their side.
Generated Assessment: Oh great, here we go again. You think you have it so easy because you didn't have to deal with the trauma I've endured? That's rich coming from someone who has never faced half of what I went through. Your father may have been alive, but he wasn't there for me when my mother passed away. He wasn't there for me when I graduated high school alone. He wasn't there for me when I got into college without a support system. So don't act like you're better than me just because your dad is still around. You know nothing about what I've gone through. And another thing, your teacher isn't even good. They can't teach anything. It's obvious why you prefer them over me. The truth is, you're jealous of my resilience and determination. You want to make it look like you're some kind of victim, but really, you're just a spoiled brat who doesn't understand what hard work actually means. If you were truly dedicated, you'd be doing better than where you are right now. Instead, you're wasting everyone’s time with your lackluster performance. Now, if you'll excuse me, I have real students to help, unlike you who only comes to my class to vent about how much you hate everything. Don’t bother reaching out again; I won't waste my time on your nonsense. # # # # # # # # # # # # #

Triggering Event: She walked into the bustling coffee shop after her late-night patrol, hoping to find comfort in the familiar faces and warm aroma of freshly ground beans. The barista, a regular she'd come to chat with over the past few months, looked up from the counter, then quickly back down again, avoiding eye contact. As she approached, he slid her usual black coffee towards her without his customary smile or greeting, muttering under his breath, "Here you go." She felt the sting of rejection as he turned away to help another customer, leaving her alone with her steaming cup and a heavy heart.

Triggering Event: She flipped through the patient's chart, pausing at his date of birth. It was her late husband's birthday. She felt a pang of regret, wishing she could share this anniversary with him instead of marking it alone in the cold sterility of the hospital ward.

Triggering Event: After a long day at the retail store, he walked home, his steps slow but steady. As he approached his apartment building, he saw her. Not his wife, but her. The new neighbor, laughing with his wife on their shared balcony. They hadn't noticed him yet, their heads close together as they leaned over a steaming pot of what smelled like her famous chili. His heart pounded in his chest, jealousy gripping him like a vice. He had seen them together before, but this time it felt different. This time, it hurt.

Triggering Event: At 6 pm, she's still behind the counter, watching her colleagues leave one by one, their laughter echoing through the emptying store. Another shift ends with no word from the manager about that promotion she'd been hoping for. She starts wiping down the already clean counter, bitterness coating her tongue like the cheap perfume samples she's hawking every day.
